column8: text
It is unlikely that you will feel ground shaking here. If you do it will be slight and cause no damage.
A few people may feel slight shaking. If you are on the upper floor of a building you are more likely to feel shaking. No damage is caused.
Shaking will be felt by people indoors and on upper floors of buildings. Parked cars may rock slightly. It would feel similar to a truck passing by on a paved road. No damage is caused.
The shaking will be felt by many indoors and some people sleeping will wake up. Windows, dishes, and doors are moved. It may feel like a truck hitting a building.
I-III. Weak to moderate shaking
VI. Strong shaking
VII. Very Strong Shaking
VII. Severe Shaking

This area is likely to flood once in the next ten years. Springtime in Missoula is the time of year to be flood aware. To check up on the Clark Fork, Bitterroot or other rivers nearby check out this link.

This area is likely to flood once in the next ten yearsSpringtime in Missoula is the time of year to be flood aware. To check up on the Clark Fork, Bitterroot or other rivers nearby check out this link. Water will begin pooling in this area and be between 1 and 3 feet deep

This  area is likely to flood once in the next ten years.Springtime in Missoula is the time of year to be flood aware. To check up on the Clark Fork, Bitterroot or other rivers nearby check out this link.The water level is between 0 and 3 feet deep.
No information is available for flooding in this area.
No information is available for flooding in this area.
This is within and area that is likely to flood once in the next ten years. This depends on the amount of snow and speed at which it melts.
It is unlikely that you will see flooding in your area.
This area is protected from flooding by a levee
This area is at risk of having a migrating river erode into it.
This is historically where the river has migrated.
This is a buffer around the current channel
This is a buffer around the channel.
No channel migration studies have been done here.
Massive flooding occurs. This area is inundated with fast moving debris filled water. Get sandbags to preotect your home and evacuate. Do not try to drive through submerged areas.

There is widespread flooding in Missoula County. This area is outside of the main areas that are flooded, but there may be patches of water on roadways and road closures. Check local emergency alerts for more information.

There is widespread flooding in Missoula County. This area is normally protected by a levee, but due to the large amounts of flood waters, levees are not working. This area becomes inundated. Check local emergency alerts for more information.

There is widespread flooding in Missoula County. This area is within 500 feet of mapped flood zones and flood waters have reached this area. Buy sand bags at local stores to protect home and check local emergency alerts for more information.
This is fire intensity 1-lowest fire hazard
This is fire intensity 2
This is fire intensity 3
This is fire intensity 4
This is fire intensity 5-highest fire hazard
This is non-burnable
This area is water and it is very unlikely wildfire will come through here.
This region could experience a catastrophic wildfire.  It will be fast moving, with large flame. It could take firefighters days to weeks to contain it.
This region is within 0.5 miles of the edge of town. If a wildfire approaches city limits you could be at risk of a fire reaching your home. There will be limited evacuation time so be prepared.
This area is farther than 0.5 miles from the edge of town and is unlikely to see wildfire.
You won't see a landslide in this area.
It is unlikely that you will see a landslide in your area.
If you live near steep slopes and ravines be aware that landslides could happen in your area. They are especially likely after a large fire and rain event.
If you live near steep slopes and ravines be aware that landslides could happen in your area. They are especially likely after a large fire and rain event.
This location does not have a record of wildfire between 1889 and 2013.

Make a flood emergency plan prior to a flood. Take pictures of valuable and make sure flood insurance is up to date.

column2: A word from your emergency managers
column8: If you live in a flood prone area you will be responsible for acquiring sand bags and filling them prior to a flood. Emergency managers' main priorities are to keep people safe and restore essential services as quickly as possible.
Sign up for emergency notifications here : https://www.smart911.com/. You can get information during an event by calling 406-258-INFO (4636)

Steps can be taken to reduce sources of fuel around your home. The National Fire Protection Association recommends a defensible space of up to 200 feet from a structure. To find out more about what you can do go here: http://www.nfpa.org/safety-information/for-consumers/emergency-preparedness/natural-disasters/wildfires

column2: A word from your emergency managers
column8: If a wildfire threatens you or your neighbor's homes, emergency managers will first make sure people are evacuated and accounted for. Affected roadways will be closed to protect people from exposure to fire. As soon as it is safe roads will be re-opened and you will be allowed back into your home.
Sign up for emergency notifications here : https://www.smart911.com/. You can get information during an event by calling 406-258-INFO (4636)

If a large earthquake were to hit Missoula County there are steps that you should take to prepare. Secure items that could fall, make a communication plan with family members, practice "Drop, cover, and hold" for more on earthquakes go to ready.gov/earthquakes

column2: A word from your emergency managers
column8: The main priority for emergency managers will be to make sure all victims are accounted for and get them to safety. Then they will focus on restoration of essential services and begin evaluation of structures.

Sign up for emergency notifications here : https://www.smart911.com/. You can get information during an event by calling 406-258-INFO (4636). The Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) meets quarterly if you want to get involved!
During a flood be aware! Stay away from fast moving water that may be contaminated and contain floating debris. Wells may be contaminated and roads and bridges may be impassable.
After a large earthquake things to be aware of are broken gas lines, foundation movement, structural issues, and power outages.
Weather is constantly changing in and around the county. In the winter be aware of cold temps and road conditions. Check the local news for weather forecasts, predictions and warnings.

Missoula County has seen blizzard like conditions before and will likely see them again. This means sustained winds or frequent gusts of 35 mph or more. At 35mph whole trees are in motion and walking around requires effort. Visibility will be reduced due to falling or blowing snow and temperatures could be in the negatives with wind chill even lower.

Extreme winter weather can halt everything in and around town and make travel by foot or car extremely hazardous. Power, heat, and communication services can be knocked out by heavy snowfall and ice.  Pipes and water mains can freeze and break.

Be smart and have essentials available to you when the power does go out. Don't risk going out in the storm if you can avoid it. Find out more about how to fully prepare here: https://www.fema.gov/media-library-data/1408633655071-32caae446efef4ab2f4fcccdb55f725c/PrepareAthon_WINTER%20STORMS_HTG_FINAL_508.pdf

Missoula County is lucky as we have a Weather Service Forecast Office in Missoula near the airport. They are on 24/7 with advisories, watches, and warnings to keep you safe if dangerous weather strikes the county. Go here for more information: http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/mso/

In February of 2014 a major storm hit the Missoula Valley dumping several feet of snow. A blizzard warning was issued and high winds loaded the surrounding peaks. On March 2nd and avalanche was triggered on Mount Jumbo that travelled into the Rattlesnake Neighborhood in the City of Missoula leading to one death, injuries, and damage to multiple homes.
Weather is constantly changing in and around the county. In the summer be aware of thunder storms, windstorms, and heat waves. Check the local news for weather forecasts, predictions and warnings.

Severe thunderstorms can happen here in Missoula County. These involve high winds, thunder, and lighting and can lead to flash flooding. It's possible to get 60-80mph winds causing widespread broken and uprooted trees and structural damage. Thunderstorms can also include hail greater than an inch in diameter.
Flash flooding is the biggest threat to safety during a summer thunderstorm. These are caused

Be smart and have essentials available to you when the power does go out. Don't risk going out in the storm if you can avoid it. Find out more about how to fully prepare here: http://www.ready.gov/thunderstorms-lightning

Missoula County is lucky as we have a Weather Service Forecast Office in Missoula near the airport. They are on 24/7 with advisories, watches, and warnings to keep you safe if dangerous weather strikes the county. Go here for more information: http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/mso/
Here's a  video showing what a flash flood can be like: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ddEIv4yHXx4
